datas.issue: A 7-year-old Birman cat with 2-day history of lethargy and tachypnoea presents with these auscultation findings. What abnormalities are present?

A 9-year-old Chihuahua presents for routine health check with this newly detected heart murmur at the left apex. No palpable thrill is detectable and physical examination is otherwise normal. What is your most likely differential diagnosis?

A 7-year-old Cocker spaniel presents for vaccination with this left apical heart murmur. Last year, a grade II murmur was detected but no notes defining the timing or localisation were made at the time. No palpable thrill is detectable and physical examination is otherwise normal. How would you grade this murmur?

This heart murmur was detected in a male Rottweiller, aged 6-months, at pre-anaesthesia assessment for neutering. A palpable thrill was present at the left base but the murmur was not audible with the stethoscope 1cm off the chest wall. How would you describe the heart murmur?

This auscultation was recorded in a 6-year-old Cavalier King Charles spaniel presented for two episodes of vomiting after dietary indiscretion. How would you describe the heart sounds at the left apex, and would you recommend further investigation?
A dog with previously diagnosed stage B1 mitral valve disease presents for vaccination and heart sounds were recorded. What abnormalities are present?
options: Quiet systolic heart murmur and sinus arrhythmia
Loud systolic heart murmur and premature beats
Loud systolic heart murmur and sinus arrhythmia
Quiet systolic murmur and sinus rhythm
datas.answer: Loud systolic heart murmur and premature beats

datas.issue: Auscultation of the left sternal border at routine health-check detects these findings in a 5-year-old, female neutered domestic shorthair cat. What abnormality is present?
A horse presents for pre-purchase examination and this is how the heart sounds. What is the abnormality detected? Consider its significance in this context.
A horse presents for routine vaccination and this murmur is audible on the left side. No precordial thrill is present. How would you describe this murmur?
